coredata.dc:title: Further evidence for core-hole effects in the near-edge structures of light-element K-edges
coredata.dc:creator: Brydson, R.
Bruley, J.
Thomas, J.M.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The importance of core-hole effects on the resultant near-edge structure of the lithium K-edge in various compounds is shown by means of modelling with real-space multiple scattering calculations. Agreement is only achieved if core-hole effects are accounted for by use of excited absorbing atom potentials - notably the (Z+1) excited state approximation for light elements. Furthermore, we report the electron-energy-loss near-edge structure of lithium carbide including the carbon K-edge which we believe to be characteristic of carbides containing the C2 2− ion.

Introduction In recent years there has been considerable inter- est in the measurement of electron-energy-loss near- edge structure (ELNES) of inner-shell excitations obtained using the technique of electron-energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS) conducted in an appropriately modified electron microscope [l 4] - Such studies allow the investigation of the electronic structure of solids by the analysis of materials of microscopic di- mension, provided they are reasonably resistant to electron-beam-induced damage. It is well known that under the conditions of small momentum transfer and small sample thickness the interpretation of ELNES follows along similar lines to that of X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES), the two techniques being complemen- tary. According to Fermi s golden rule the core edge intensity is directly proportional to the projected density of unoccupied states of the appropriate sym- metry, provided the matrix element overlap factor (which describes the coupling between the initial and final states within the dipole selection rule) is slowly varying over the near-edge energy region [5]. In Current address: Thomas J. Watson Research Centre, P.O. Box 218, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, USA. reality, however, this simple single-electron picture is often modified by relaxation of the unexcited elec- trons in response to the production of a core hole as well as excited-electron core-hole interactions F6,71. In some cases single-electron theory has been suc- cessful in the interpretation of near-edge structures produced by electron-energy-loss [8 10] and X-ray absorption measurements E 11,12]; but as we have shown previously the presence of the core hole can have drastic effects on observed near-edge features especially in low-Z-element K-edges [13]. In a previous work [131 we demonstrated that the experimentally measured ELNES of the beryllium and boron K-edges in the naturally occurring min- eral rhodizite could be modelled by real-space mul- tiple scattering calculations provided core-hole effects were taken into account by use of the (Z+ 1) excited state approximation for the central absorbing atom. Such calculations are performed using the ICXANES computer code of Vvedensky et al. [14], which permits the calculation of the transition rate for excitation within the dipole approximation using essentially an atomic contribution modified by multiple scattering of the excited electron by the sur- rounding atoms. This approach, while essentially equivalent to a Korringa Kohn Rostocker (KKR) band structure calculation, is considerably more O 009-2614/88/$ 03.50 ~ Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) 343 Volume 149, number 4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 26August1988 flexible since it permits the inclusion of excited atom potentials to account for core-hole effects as we have previously shown. The scattering properties of the various atoms are described by phase shifts which may be calculated by numerical integration of the Schrodinger equation assuming a muffin tin form for the atomic potentials in the crystal (obtained via the Mattheiss prescription by the superposition of neu- tral atomic charge densities [15,16]). The multiple scattering is then performed in real space by dividing the cluster into shells of atoms surrounding the ab- sorbing atom, the multiple scattering is solved within each shell in turn and the results combined so as to reassemble the final cluster; use being made of any structural symmetry. Having indicated the magnitude of core-hole ef- fects on the near-edge structure of the beryllium and boron K-edges, we wished to continue this work by studying such effects on the lithium K-edges in a va- riety of compounds. For illustration here we report on lithium fluoride, LiF, and lithium carbide, Li2C2. Further work is in progress on other samples con- taining light elements. 2. Experimental The materials under study were obtained as com- mercially available reagent grade samples in powder or lump form, and were checked using X-ray powder diffraction (XRD). They were then transferred to electron microscope grids by grinding, suspension in acetone and pippetting (in the case of LiF), or sim- ply grinding and dusting (in the case of Li2C2). Lith- ium carbide is moderately sensitive to attack from moisture in the atmosphere and the standard pre- cautions were observed. Experiments were per- formed in a VU HB5O 1 dedicated scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM) operat- ing at 100 key and fitted with a field emission source and VU magnetic prism spectrometer having an op- timum energy resolution of 0.5 eV. The collection and convergence semi-angles were 8 and 2 mrad re- spectively. The vacuum in the specimen chamber was better than 5 X 10- ~ and none of the specimens showed any evidence of contamination. EELS spec- tra were recorded by serially scanning the electron beam across a slit by ramping the applied drift tube voltage, this technique facilitating the accurate cal- ibration of absolute energies [17]. The subsequent processing of the EELS spectra was performed using the standard techniques of Fourier-log deconvolu- tion and background subtraction which are fully de- scribed in the work of Egerton [3]. 3. We have included six shells around the central absorbing atom (corre- sponding to a radius of approximately 10 au) to- gether with a damping of 1 eV. To achieve agree- ment with the very strong first peak in the experimental spectrum, we found that we had to em- ploy the (Z+ 1) excited state (in our nomenclature (Z+ 1 )*) approximation for the central absorbing atom. In other words we replaced the central lithium atom in the cluster with an atom with the configu- ration Be ls 2s22p (i.e. having an atomic number Z= 3). Any attempt to use ground state wavefunc- tions (Z approximation), Z excited state wavefunc- tions (~ approximation), or (Z+ 1) ground state wavefunctions ((Z+ 1)0 approximation) resulted in an initial peak intensity that was much too low rel- ative to the second peak. Beryllium and boron in te- trahedral coordination to oxygen showed a similar effect [13]. Such empirical modelling of the central atom potential seems to correctly account for the re- laxation and screening of the remaining electrons in response to core-hole production in the case of low- Z-element K-edges. By using photoemission Stott et al. [21] have de- termined the separation of the Lit ls level in LiF from the top of the valence band, and if this is com- bined with the band gap of 14.2 eV it implies that the onset of core- to conduction-band transitions oc- curs at 64 eV. Thus according to the prescription of Pantelides [221, the dominant feature present in the experimental spectrum at 61.9 eV is due to a s pp allowed exciton, whereas the weak pre-structure centred at around 58 eV (seen more clearly in the spectra of Stott et al. [21] and Gudat et al. [23]) is thought to be assigned to an 5-ts forbidden exci- ton band. This is confirmed by our calculations which predict the presence of the first peak at 61.9 eV, only if the core hole is taken into account. Accordingly since the ICXANES approach works within the di- pole selection rule the forbidden s ~ s structure is not reproduced. The absolute transition energies to the bound excitonic states have been computed by Kunz et al. [24] and these results agree well with experiment. Other workers have attempted to model the Li K- edge in LiF using short-range order multiple scat- tering calculations, notably Nakai et al. [25], who employed the (Z+ 1)0 approximation for the core hole together with an ionicity of Li 7~F 7 (de- duced so as to match with experiment). Our own calculations assume no such ionicity. Clearly a self- consistent calculation is required but it has been shown that, as far as XANES is concerned, the non- self-consistent Mattheiss prescription gives a suffi- ciently accurate approximation to a fully self-con- sistent calculation even in ionic materials such as calcium oxide, CaO [26,271. Although the proper inclusion of the ionicity is undoubtedly important, we believe that the major concem in ICXANES-type calculations should be the correct representation of the potential due to the core hole. Certainly the edge onset is considerably lower than that of the C K-edge in amorphous car- bon (285 eV [32]) and the C K-edge in carbonates (289 eV [33]), suggesting the presence of a nega- tively charged carbon species. Thus we believe that a combination of the energy position and gross features of the spec- trum in fig. 3 is characteristic of the C~ ion. Fur- thermore, it is interesting to compare this spectrum with that of the C K-edge in Be2C [35]. In this car- bide isolated C atoms exist in an antifluorite struc- ture; consequently no feature analogous to peak (a) in fig. 3 is observed. 4. Conclusions We present further evidence for the importance of core-hole effects on the near-edge structure of light- element K-edges. Our empirical modelling proce- dure allows inclusion of these effects in real-space multiple scattering calculations. In doing so we at- tempt to lay the groundwork for the use of EELS as a routine probe of the local structural and chemical environment around an atom. In particular, we dem- onstrate what we believe to be an EELS finger- print for carbides containing the C~ group. Acknowledgement We wish to express our thanks to Dr. L.M.
